title: 112_s913
content: The Act titled "Do-Not-Track Online Act of 2011" establishes regulations for "Do-Not-Track" mechanisms. The Federal Trade Commission must establish regulations for a mechanism allowing individuals to indicate their preference on personal information collection by online service providers. Providers are prohibited from collecting information on individuals who express a preference against it, with exceptions allowed under specific rules. The Federal Trade Commission will allow the collection and use of personal information on individuals, even if they express a preference against it, under certain conditions. These conditions include providing necessary services requested by the individual and obtaining clear consent for the collection and use of information. The Federal Trade Commission will consider the scope, technical feasibility, and costs of implementing mechanisms for individuals to indicate their preference on personal information collection by online service providers. The Federal Trade Commission will consider standards for personal information collection by online service providers, including mobile applications. This includes publicizing mechanisms, collecting information anonymously, and setting standards for data collection and usage. The Federal Trade Commission will promulgate standards and rules for online services, including mobile applications, to respect individuals' preferences regarding personal information collection. The Federal Trade Commission will establish standards and rules for online services and mobile applications to comply with section 553 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 3. ENFORCEMENT OF ``DO-NOT-TRACK'' MECHANISMS. The Federal Trade Commission enforces rules regarding unfair or deceptive acts or practices under the Act, treating violations as such. The Commission has the same enforcement powers, means, jurisdiction, and duties as under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Act enforces penalties for violations and grants privileges and immunities similar to the Federal Trade Commission Act. Nonprofit organizations are also subject to enforcement. States' attorneys general can enforce the Act as well. The attorney general of a State can bring a civil action on behalf of residents to address violations of rules by individuals, seeking injunctions, compliance, damages, and other appropriate relief in federal court. The attorney general of a State can bring a civil action on behalf of residents to address violations of rules by individuals, seeking injunctions, compliance, damages, and other appropriate relief in federal court. Civil penalties for violating rules under section 2(a)(2) can be imposed, with a maximum total liability of $15,000,000. The penalty amount is calculated based on the number of days of non-compliance, not exceeding $16,000 per day. The maximum total liability for civil actions under section 2(a)(2) is $15,000,000. The penalty amount will be adjusted for inflation annually based on the Consumer Price Index. The Federal Trade Commission has rights to receive notice regarding violations. The attorney general of a State must notify the Federal Trade Commission before bringing a civil action, except in cases where it is not feasible to do so. The notification should include a copy of the complaint to be filed. When initiating a civil action, the attorney general must notify the Federal Trade Commission immediately. The FTC can intervene in the action, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal. No limitations on investigatory powers in this subsection. The attorney general of a State has investigatory powers to conduct investigations, administer oaths, compel witnesses, and evidence production. If the FTC takes action on a violation, the State attorney general cannot bring a civil action against the same defendant during the FTC's action. The attorney general of a State has investigatory powers to conduct investigations, administer oaths, compel witnesses, and evidence production. Any civil action brought under paragraph (1) may be brought in a district court of the United States or another court of competent jurisdiction. Process may be served in any district where the defendant is an inhabitant or may be found. Additionally, other state officials can take actions in civil cases. State officials authorized by the State can bring civil actions under the same requirements as attorneys general. This subsection does not prevent State officials from pursuing legal proceedings for violations of State laws. The Federal Trade Commission must conduct a biennial review and assessment of the regulations under the Act within 2 years. This includes evaluating the effectiveness of the regulations, particularly in defining "personal information," and analyzing their impact on online commerce. A report on the findings must be submitted to Congress.
